subject: Re: [junit] Definitions question
msgSnippet: ... I warned you, and you accepted the warning. I did my job. :) ... Understood. Do you see why I don t say unit test ? :) I don t know that there is a
messageBody:
Chappell, Simon P wrote:

> >> All wisdom on this matter will be greatly appreciated.
> >
> >Here's wisdom that nevertheless doesn't help you: it doesn't matter.
>
> JB, that's good wisdom, but you're right, it doesn't answer my question.

I warned you, and you accepted the warning. I did my job. :)

> >If they're getting hung up on what words mean in some ethereal objective
> >sense, rather than simply finding a workable vocabulary to help with
> >their current discussion, then I have to wonder whether they
> >care about
> >communicating at all.
>
> We actually are working on the shared vocabiulary at this time, which is
> why I asked. I would prefer that we use accepted terminology, but I need
> some definitive source to show people, so that they will accept it.
> Otherwise, we'll be using the terminology that the process police give
> us. :-(
>
> Remember: large companies don't do anything until they've defined what
> they're gonna call everything.
>
> You know you're up against an interesting challenge, when one of the
> questions from an attendee is "What's a unit?"

Understood. Do you see why I don't say "unit test"? :)

I don't know that there is a definitive source that I would care to use.
You might wish to ask this question on a group like software-testing or
agile-testing.
--
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
Diaspar Software Services
